what: Helpers for Data Preparation, Descriptives, Models, & Publication
title: Helpers for Data Preparation, Descriptives, Models, & Publication
text: gentleman package provides suite modules help data preparation, descriptive statistics, modeling, publication formatting. Descriptives module extensible accommodate custom functions generate tables p-values (useful statistic compare groups). Models module can used generate lavaan model strings mediation cross-lagged models.

title: Helpers for Data Preparation, Descriptives, Models, & Publication
text: can install gentleman public repository GitHub :

title: Helpers for Data Preparation, Descriptives, Models, & Publication
text: installed, can use package loading R session.

title: Helpers for Data Preparation, Descriptives, Models, & Publication
text: package composed several modules accomplish related tasks (see reference page complete list functions): Data preparation Descriptive statistics Models Clusters Machine learning Logger Helpers

title: Helpers for Data Preparation, Descriptives, Models, & Publication
text: data preparation module, can clean manipulate data.frames, recode variables modify factors. example:
code: # Remove non-ASCII characters and variables with too many missing values, # cast character vars as factors, and remove factors with too many categories df <- df |>    remove_non_ascii_from_df() |>    remove_vars_with_too_many_missing(pmissing=.80) |>    cast("character", "factors") |>    remove_blank_factor_levels() |>    remove_factors_with_too_many_levels(maxlevels=20)  # Recode 'Nationality' using a lookup table in an Excel file df$Nationality <- df$Nationality |>    recode_using_excel_map("map.xlsx", sheet="Nationality")  # Use effect coding for factors in regression and other models options(contrasts=c(unordered="contr.dummy_or_effect",                      ordered="contr.poly"))

title: Helpers for Data Preparation, Descriptives, Models, & Publication
text: package equipped extensive customizable module descriptive statistics. particular, can generate publication-ready tables descriptive statistics numeric categorical variables, optionally added columns group-specific statistics group comparison. example: get_desc_table() function workhorse module, takes arguments: tbl_fn: function returns table statistics given variables; package comes tbl_fn_num() numeric variables, tbl_fn_fac() categorical (factor) variables ana_fn: function returns table test statistics (typically p-values) compare groups set variables; package comes ana_fn_aov() ana_fn_rm_aov() (repeated) numeric variables (p-values ANOVA), ana_fn_chisq() categorical (factor) variables (p-values Chi-square tests) can develop custom tbl_fn ana_fn functions wish pass arguments get_desc_table(), take care rest. module can also used detect variables vary within persons groups, plot densities groups.
code: # Get a table of descriptive statistics for numeric variables # and test for group differences by treatment group df |> get_desc_table(   vars=c("age", "score"),   tbl_fn=tbl_fn_num(),   group="TreatmentGroup",   ana_fn=ana_fn_aov() )  # Get a table of descriptive statistics for factor variables # and test for group differences by treatment group df |> get_desc_table(   vars=c("Nationality", "Diagnostic"),   tbl_fn=tbl_fn_fac(),   group="TreatmentGroup",   ana_fn=ana_fn_chisq() ) # Test mean differences between subscales df |> compare_pairs_of_vars(c("x1", "x2", "x3"))  # Get all variables that significantly vary by groups df |> get_sig_differences_between_groups(group="TreatmentGroup")  # Plot densities by group df |> plot_density_by_groups(group="TreatmentGroup")

title: Helpers for Data Preparation, Descriptives, Models, & Publication
text: models module can generate lavaan syntax estimate complex mediation cross-lagged models: module can also used decompose 2-way interactions different types models (like lm lmer): Similar descriptives module, can generate publication-ready tables different types models can copy-paste, example Excel. Effects formatted 2 decimals leading zero, significance indicated common standards using asterisks. Currently, publication tables available lavaan models models can summarized using broom (like lm glm). ’ve generated publication tables several models, can compare significant effects publication tables:
code: library(lavaan)  # Mediation model with one x, one mediator, and one y get_mediation_model("x1", "x2", "x3") |>   sem(df) |>   summary()  # Cross-lagged model with 3 different variables assessed at 3 occasions each vars <- list(   c("x1", "x2", "x3"),   c("y1", "y2", "y3"),   c("z1", "z2", "z3") ) get_crosslagged_model(vars, random_intercepts=FALSE) |>   sem(df) |>   summary() fit <- lm(SelfEsteem ~ Gender*AttitudeTowardsSchool, df) fit |> decompose_interaction(x1="Gender", x2="AttitudeTowardsSchool") # Generate a publication table for two regressions using lavaan  # and full-information maximum likelihood estimation library(lavaan) fit_lavaan <- list() fit_lavaan$y1 <- sem("y1 ~ x1+x2", df, missing="ml.x") fit_lavaan$y2 <- sem("y2 ~ x1+x2", df, missing="ml.x") pub_lavaan <- fit_lavaan |> make_pub_table_from_lavaan_models()  # Generate a publication table for two regressions with OLS estimation  # and listwise deletion of missing data library(broom) fit_lm <- list() fit_lm$y1 <- lm(y1 ~ x1+x2, df) |> tidy() fit_lm$y2 <- lm(y2 ~ x1+x2, df) |> tidy() pub_lm <- fit_lm |> make_pub_table_from_broom_tidy() # Sensitivity analysis: effect of missing data pub_lm |> compare_sig_effects_in_two_pub_tables(pub_lavaan)

title: Helpers for Data Preparation, Descriptives, Models, & Publication
text: Clustering can performed easily mixed types variables missing data. module uses cluster package first calculate distance matrices based Gower distances, generate clusters around medoids. desired number clusters can specified, can determined automatically via NbClust package. module also implements iterative variable selection procedure, variables kept clustering process related final cluster assignments.
code: # Generate 3 clusters using all variables df |> get_cluster(k=3) # Generate clusters with variable selection using an optimal number of clusters # and plot densities of variables on which clusters significantly vary df |>   add_cluster_assignment(k=NULL,                           maxit=10,                           return_df_cluster_instead=TRUE) |>   plot_density_by_groups(group="Cluster")

title: Helpers for Data Preparation, Descriptives, Models, & Publication
text: machine learning module provides functions support development ML pipelines, particularly supervised learning. can split training test sets, scale numeric features sets using information training set, remove target test set prevent target leakage (implementation method discussed ). module also offers interface generate process AutoML model using h2o library, can used add predictions test set retrieve variable importances. module also comes AutoML pipeline built-, takes data.frame, splits training test sets, prepares h2o, requests AutoML model obtains predictions variable importances. example:
code: # Split into train-test sets, scale numeric features, # and remove target from test set to prevent target leakage tt <- df |>    ttsplit(prop_train=.67) |>    scale_numeric_features_in_train_and_test() |>    remove_target_from_test_and_add_ref_to_env(target="y1",                                               unique_id="id",                                               ref_name="target_values") # AutoML pipeline with default configuration (random forest), # 70%-30% train-test split, scaled numeric features, # confidence levels for predictions, and variable importances pip <- df |> run_automl_pipeline(target="y1",                                  prop_train=.7,                                  scale_numeric_features=TRUE,                                  add_confidence_level=TRUE,                                  plot_and_print_variable_importances=TRUE)

title: Helpers for Data Preparation, Descriptives, Models, & Publication
text: logger module offers simple way log console output text file disk. logs saved given directory folder called gentleman_logs, file name can optionally specified (default file name current date time). Logs can updated passing logger object. module can also used retrieve information latest commit git repository.
code: # Simple one-time log logtext(expr={   print("model without covariates:")   lm(y1 ~ x1, df) |> summary() |> print()      print("model with covariates")   lm(y1 ~ x1 + x2 + x3, df) |> summary() |> print() })  # Create a logger with git information and update log logger <- get_logger(fname="models with and without covariates", add_git_info=TRUE) logger |> logtext(expr={   print("model without covariates:")   lm(y1 ~ x1, df) |> summary() |> print() }) logger |> logtext(expr={   print("model with covariates")   lm(y1 ~ x1 + x2 + x3, df) |> summary() |> print() })

what: Add cluster with iterative variable selection — add_cluster_assignment
title: Add cluster with iterative variable selection — add_cluster_assignment
text: function adds cluster assignment row data.frame iterative variable selection clustering.

title: Add cluster with iterative variable selection — add_cluster_assignment
code: add_cluster_assignment(   df,   v_cluster = NULL,   k = NULL,   maxit = 10,   return_df_cluster_instead = FALSE,   new_var_name = "Cluster" )

title: Add cluster with iterative variable selection — add_cluster_assignment
text: df data.frame v_cluster (character) vector variable names use clustering (NULL, use ) k (numeric) number clusters (NULL, determined optimally; see get_cluster()) maxit (numeric) maximum number iterations select significant outcomes clusters return_df_cluster_instead (logical) whether return df final clustering variables cluster assignment (default FALSE) new_var_name (character) new variable name

title: Add cluster with iterative variable selection — add_cluster_assignment
text: df new cluster variable added

title: Add cluster with iterative variable selection — add_cluster_assignment
text: initial set clusters determined using get_cluster() (Gower distance matrix clustering around medoids). , significant differences clusters determined using get_sig_differences_between_groups() (ANOVA numeric variables, Chi-square categorical variables), clustering performed using reduced set significant variables. variable-reduction method repeated remaining variables significant, maxit reached. maxit reached convergence, warning thrown. maxit set 0, warning thrown indicating variable selection performed, equivalent using get_cluster() directly.

title: Add cluster with iterative variable selection — add_cluster_assignment
code: if (FALSE) { df <- df |> add_cluster_assignment()  df |>    add_cluster_assignment(return_df_cluster_instead=TRUE) |>    plot_density_by_groups(group="Cluster") }

Add predictions from an AutoML object to a test set — add_predictions_from_automl
text: automl H2O AutoML object (h2o::h2o.automl() get_automl_model()) tt train-test list (see ttsplit()) tt_h2o H2O pointers train test frames (see ship_train_and_test_to_h2o()) add_confidence_level (logical) whether add confidence levels alongside predictions test set (default TRUE)

title: Add predictions from an AutoML object to a test set — add_predictions_from_automl
code: if (FALSE) { init_h2o() tt <- df |> ttsplit() tt_h2o <- tt |> ship_train_and_test_to_h2o() automl <- tt_h2o |> get_automl_model(target="y1") tt <- add_predictions_from_automl(automl) }

title: Compare significant effects from two publication tables — compare_sig_effects_in_two_pub_tables
code: library(lavaan) #> This is lavaan 0.6-12 #> lavaan is FREE software! Please report any bugs. ana <- list() ana$y1 <- sem("y1 ~ x1+x2", df, missing="ml.x") ana$y2 <- sem("y2 ~ x1+x2", df, missing="ml.x") pub_sem <- ana |> make_pub_table_from_lavaan_models()  library(broom) ana <- list() ana$y1 <- lm(y1 ~ x1+x2, df) |> tidy() ana$y2 <- lm(y2 ~ x1+x2, df) |> tidy() pub_lm <- ana |> make_pub_table_from_broom_tidy()  # sensitivity analysis: effect of missing data pub_lm |> compare_sig_effects_in_two_pub_tables(pub_sem) #> _______________________________ #> * in table1 but not in table2: #> character(0) #> _______________________________ #> * in table2 but not in table1: #> character(0)
